intro: Vieusseuxia unguicularis, commonly known as the black mangrove, is a flowering plant species native to coastal regions of the Americas. It is characterized by its dark, almost black bark and its ability to thrive in saline and brackish water environments. The plant has small, clustered white flowers that bloom throughout the year, and its leaves are typically opposite and oval-shaped. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing coastal soils and providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial organisms. Vieusseuxia unguicularis is also notable for its unique root system, which includes pneumatophores that aid in oxygen absorption in waterlogged soils.
